executive_summary: The Excavation Contractors industry earns nearly half of its revenue from the private residential and nonresidential building markets. The remainder stems from the excavation of land in nonbuilding construction markets, including sports fields, roadwork and water supply facilities. Over the five years to 2023, the industry stagnated as rising interest rates and COVID-19 complications mitigated industry demand. Excavation Contractors industry revenue has been inching upward at a CAGR of 0.9% over the past five years.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: The Industry Swelled Amid the Robust Pandemic Housing Market
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The construction of major apartment buildings, condominiums and residential houses requires extensive excavation services to accommodate these large-scale operations. Excavation contractors have relied on a healthy housing market for a large portion of business. Housing starts and the value of residential construction shot up amid the COVID-19 pandemic. This was due to the Federal Reserve

Over the next five years, growth will resume even as residential construction stalls compared with the prior period. Nonresidential construction activity will pick up, offsetting weakness in the residential market segment. Similarly, torrid growth in trenching and nonbuilding construction activities, such as road and waterway construction, following the Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act (IIJA) will combat rising interest rates and the slowdown in housing starts.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Rising Costs Hinder the Industry's Expansion
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Climbing interest rates, though, have made funding new housing projects expensive. Housing trends have reversed, slamming contractors with waves of volatility. Also, the price of key inputs, namely oil and steel, has piled onto rising interest rates. Excavation contractors have paid significantly more to transport workers and operate heavy machinery including excavators and forklifts.

Contractors have benefited from a significant uptick in government funding for infrastructure. Rebuilding American Infrastructure with Sustainability and Equity (RAISE) grants and the Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act have given state and local governments the financial flexibility to fund infrastructure projects.

Associated Builders and Contractors (ABC) reports that the construction sector faces a major labor shortage. In 2023, the construction workforce shortage tops half a million workers. This trend has hindered construction activity from matching construction spending, piling onto already harmful inflation and interest rate activity. Increased demand for skilled workers has boosted labor fees, hindering profit.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: In its 2021 Report Card for US Infrastructure, the American Society of Civil Engineers gave both the nation's roads and aviation infrastructure a grade of D and D+, respectively, indicating an inadequate national transportation network. Governments have endured mounting pressure to allocate more funding to road, highway and airport runway construction and repair.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: THE NONRESIDENTIAL MARKET CREATES AN ENTRY OPPORTUNITY
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The nonresidential construction market will recuperate following pandemic-induced lows. In fact, the value of private nonresidential construction is set to increase year-over-year over the next five years, bolstered by renewed business sentiment and increased economic activity.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Companies Will Turn to Subcontractors to Limit Wage Costs
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: As costs continue to rise, companies will turn to subcontracted labor for payroll flexibility. Subcontractors are paid on a per-contract basis, so companies can quickly reduce workforces and cut costs when no projects are available. As the economy continues to improve, though, buyers will make more contracts available, attracting a multitude of new entrants.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Government Spending Will Spur Demand from the Technology Sector
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Similar to the Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act (IIJA), the Creating Helpful Incentives to Produce Semiconductors (CHIPS) and Science Act will create significant demand for excavation contractors. Many excavation contractors will benefit from elevated demand for mega-projects associated with chip manufacturing plants, clean energy facilities and related green infrastructure.

industry_definition: This industry primarily excavates land for building construction. Activities include drilling shafts, foundation digging and drilling and grading. The excavation work performed includes new work, additions, alterations and repairs.
key_trends: Rising interest rates have made funding new projects difficult.
Larger companies have an easier time weathering declining demand, while smaller companies must either exit the industry or consolidate to remain competitive.
Federal funding, such as the Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act has increased for public infrastructure, creating entry opportunities
Excavation contractors supported by government spending
Growing regulations on health and safety
A declining residential construction market has put pressure on profit
Subcontracted labor takes pressure off of the labor market. Subcontractors provide companies with greater flexibility and offers specialized services on-demand.

market_segmentation.segment_description: Excavation projects in the nonbuilding market include recreational infrastructures, such as sporting fields, parklands or golf courses. Municipal buildings include hospitals, clinics, medical centers, schools, law courts, prisons, churches, police and fire stations and more. This market also incorporates things often funded by government entities such as roadwork, including driveways and parking lots; and subcontracted work excavating for water and sewer infrastructure. The Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act (IIJA) provides more than $550.0 billion for domestic infrastructure and municipal building projects. It will create a plethora of opportunities for new and existing contractors in these market segments. The benefits of this have already been seen as the number of industry enterprises increases.

High office vacancies amid the pandemic stifled growth in the nonresidential market. Businesses were unwilling to invest in new offices while uncertainty surrounded a return to normal work. High interest rates hindered the construction of new nonresidential buildings and structures, as these projects are often financed. Still, the elimination of COVID-related restrictions and increased government funding has boosted demand in 2023 and this is set to continue over the outlook period. The manufacturing sector, though, will carry this segment. Demand for new factories has shot up as the United States attempts to reduce its reliance on foreign goods, especially amid growing geopolitical conflicts with Russia and China.

Residential construction activity surged during the pandemic as individuals moved out of major cities. In particular, the surge in housing starts created a strong market. Even so, rising interest rates in the latter half of the period stalled the market. Financing new projects grew more expensive and many individuals turned to renovations instead of building new structures. The building of new structures is the industry's largest revenue source, so declines in this segment hinders industry growth.

products_and_services.product_description: Land Development and Subdivision in Australia, Site Preparation Services in Australia, Site Preparation in the UK, Land Development and Subdivision in New Zealand, Site Preparation Services in New Zealand, Demolition & Site Preparation in Ireland

More specialized large-scale contractors undertake deep foundation construction, including drilled and driven piles. Amid the COVID-19 pandemic, the number of housing starts skyrocketed as people left big cities and adapted to work-from-home routines. Foundation digging services reached a new high. Even so, rising interest rates have pushed down demand for foundation digging services, similar to excavation services. Cash-strapped homeowners and businesses have preferred less expensive renovations to completely new projects.

Nonbuilding and trenching activities, such as the construction of highways, streets, waterways and sewers, have less exposure to economic fluctuations. Other private earthmoving work occurs in the rural sector, specifically for the construction of dams, irrigation development and the construction of internal roads to private properties. Some contractors develop relationships with large general construction companies to undertake subcontracting work on highways, streets, private driveways and parking projects. The maintenance of sewers and roads is perceived as essential while new homes and offices are discretionary. Demand for trenching and nonbuilding activities is often cyclical– every few years a municipality or state will update its infrastructure. These services also tend to be more reliant on public money. The recent Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act will grant many states the money to update roadways. The American Society of Civil Engineers gave both the nation's roads and aviation infrastructure a grade of D and D+, respectively. New excavation work will be in high demand over the outlook period to rectify this.

business_locations.location_description: Excavation work in the Great Lakes is often used for land reclamation adjoining the lake and river systems. As the US manufacturing sector continues to recover, there will be increased demand for new factories, foundries and warehouses. Contractors will flock to the Great Lakes region and serve the manufacturing hub. This region also benefits from close proximity to Canada, which enables easy trade access to downstream manufacturing industries.

The Southeast region has the highest excavation contractors activity, correlating with strong population growth in the region. The region includes Florida, which boasts several high-density, commercially developed cities including Miami, Orlando, Tampa and Jacksonville, among others. Natural disasters, such as hurricanes, are more common in the Southeast region. Excavation services are essential in the cleanup and rebuilding process. Demand for cleanup work is more consistent compared with new construction, making the Southeast a key industry market.

California has the single-most establishments of any state in the United States. It's home to several large and expensive real estate markets, including San Francisco and Los Angeles. California is particularly attractive due to its large consumer markets. The West region also contains a large portion of the country's economic activity. Specifically, the growing technology sector is constantly requiring new office buildings and manufacturing plants.

regulations_points.regulation_title: The Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) Regulations
regulations_points.regulation_description: Health and safety regulations require that protective clothing and helmets are worn on-site and that safe conditions are provided for workers, including scaffolding, harnesses and ventilation depending on the job. OSHA enforces standards for the construction industry, which are contained in Title 29 of the Code of Federal Regulations (CFR) Part 1926. State and local building authorities assess and enforce this code. Adherence to the OSHA regulations will limit exposure to workplace accident litigation and prevent high insurance premiums.

Training for competent person certification entails knowledge of excavation, trench, sloped excavations and the maximum permissible slope; understanding of soil types; understanding of hazards posed by excavations; knowledge of shoring systems, shielding and support systems; and safety procedures on the work site. New employees must undergo extensive training in each of these topics.

Excavators are also required to hold specific licenses for each type of heavy equipment used on a site. The range of equipment covered by licenses includes the following: backhoe and excavator, dozer and scraper, front-end loader, motor grader and skid steer and commercial vehicles.
Regulations and licensing governing the use of explosives for large-scale excavation projects enforce standards on the operation and preclude entry of unqualified contractors.

Noise regulation is governed by the US Code, which is a source of federal law enacted by Congress. The law lists the types of machinery considered and requires the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) to monitor progress through developed noise emission standards.

In response to Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) guidance, various levels of regulation have been implemented in the United States and overseas to discourage public gathering, large events or crowded, unsafe work environments. Restrictions are easing in 2023 due to the widespread distribution of the COVID-19 vaccine.

basis_points.basis_description: Reputation is a key factor when companies bid for new contracts. Projects are frequently awarded to companies that have nurtured long-term relationships with developers.
Contractors compete on price and quality. Companies must take into account possible delays and plan for contingencies when submitting lowest bids.

concentration_points.concentration_description: The market consists of small contractors
The three largest companies currently generate less than 5.0% of the industry's combined revenue. Nonemployers are the industry's driving force, as most industry companies are small in size.

Despite smaller companies encompassing the majority of industry enterprises, these contractors lack the necessary resources to bid on larger and more lucrative projects. Major companies are often shielded from the negative externalities that hinder smaller companies.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Contractors remain vulnerable to purchase price fluctuations
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Purchases as a share of revenue have increased over the past five years. This segment includes the purchase of heavy equipment and machinery needed for land excavation; these types of purchases, though, tend to be cyclical. Small contractors, too, lack the capital to purchase and upgrade equipment, choosing to rent or lease to keep costs low which increases depreciation costs. The price of key inputs, such as gasoline, lumber and steel, have also added to purchasing costs. Oil, particularly, has wildly fluctuated in price following the pandemic. It has been more expensive to run excavators and other heavy machinery.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Other Regulations Cause Licensing Costs to Add Up
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Other costs as a share of revenue have increased over the past five years. While licensing costs and regulations vary by state, these fees present a significant upfront cost. Contractors also provide insurance for employees; given the manual nature of the work, insurance premiums tend to be high. Operators will also incur significant vehicle costs since travel between worksites is required. Overall, other costs account for 14.8% of revenue.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Rising Purchase and Labor Fees Hinders Profit
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Profit as a share of revenue has decreased over the past five years. The industry swelled amid the COVID-19 pandemic, riding on a torrid housing market. High interest rates, though, have limited growth in recent years. Since projects are more expensive to fund, the availability of contracts has dried up. As demand for construction has waned, profit has slipped. Also, rising wage and purchase costs have stifled any growth generated through government projects and funding.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: The Popularity of Subcontracted Labor Offsets Swelling Wage Costs
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Wages as a share of revenue have increased over the past five years. Companies are hiring subcontractors in an attempt to cut down on costs – subcontractors are paid on a per-project basis and are not kept on an operator's books nor eligible for benefits given to full-time employees.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: Skilled labor is essential to success
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Workers are needed every step of the way from planning to operating heavy machinery. Relying on subcontracted labor can lower initial labor requirements.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: Low rate of new patent technologies
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: The rate of new patent technologies entering the industry is low, which limits the potential for innovations. A low rate does not mean that innovations cannot occur, just that the likelihood of some innovation materializing as a threat is lower.
However, the concentration of technologies is high in this industry. This suggests that industry operators have exposure to potentially unforeseen areas of innovation.

The major markets for this industry are highly concentrated, which implies that the market has a focus on key customer segments. This presents an opportunity for strategic entrance into lower-end markets or unserved markets for innovations to take on a disruptive trajectory.

volatility_points.volatility_description: Rising interest rates have made it more expensive to fund new projects and source necessary inputs. In particular, loans and mortgages have become more expensive.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Fluctuations in input prices create volatility
volatility_points.volatility_description: Fluctuations in input prices, too, will create volatility. High oil prices make running heavy machinery, for example, more expensive. Purchase costs have increased over the past five years.
Housing starts have plummeted amid heightened interest rates. Without the need for excavation or foundation services, contractors have seen contracts dry up in 2022 and 2023.

The main activity undertaken in excavation work for residential and nonresidential buildings includes land clearing and leveling work on residential subdivisions and work associated with factories, warehouses or other commercial premises. Contractors sometimes have an equity interest in developing serviced housing blocks and may subcontract specific aspects of the excavation work to specialists or smaller contractors, such as compaction and dredging. The residential excavation market buoyed excavation services while nonresidential services stalled. Rising interest rates have slammed this segment, making it difficult for potential developers to fund new projects and limiting potential profit. Despite rising interest rates, nonresidential construction work is beginning to increase due to heightened consumer activity. This will enable downstream companies to be able to properly plan out and execute large-scale projects.

FAQs.question: What level of industry assistance is provided?
What is the role of unions in the excavation industry?
FAQs.answer: Many contractors choose to join unions or broader construction associations, such as the Building Contractors Association of New York City, that lobby on behalf of workers for better work environments, pay or benefits. These associations also provide a network for excavators to other construction industries, lawyers, real estate agents and politicians. Many of these associations represent the industry within a city or state instead of a single, national entity.
